comments.body: wouldn't it make sense to auto-generate these classes? (as they are basically the same except for a parameter)
I read your note above again. So this is an auto-transformer doing this? Then we can come back in a 'fix' this (e.g. not make it blow up the code like this).

These would actually be the most complex to auto-generate, as they're being dynamically created with a `.format()` call (which was already broken in a number of cases). I agree in principle but it'll be faster to just manually clean this up later as it'll be really easy to identify code for de-duplication.

I don't think we should try to auto-generate them, also not after cleaning it up manually.
- Use this auto-converted and long code for now as the initial start (the other things like being able to compare against commit, update the perf_test scripts etc are more important initially)
- Afterwards we can clean this up and deduplicate code, but then I would just use standard subclassing/reusing of functions etc to achieve that instead of some auto-generation of classes.
I agree. Maybe could put a comment on what we think should be 'fixed' later.

@jreback Sorry, didn't see your second note. Yes, this is entirely auto-transformed. It _should_ be easy to deduplicate based on shared `setup()`, but I couldn't find any good documentation on how to heavily edit the AST like this.

Basically, my approach would be to do one pass with the existing fix-ups, then create a mapping of `{setup(): [class nodes with setup()]}`, and do a second pass to merge similar class nodes. What I couldn't find docs on was a concise way to move/delete entire nodes so all the similar classes could be merged into a single class.
